item.title: Starter
item.dc:creator: @Free Free
item.description:
@Free wrote:

[quote=“Rog3r, post:23, topic:228875”]Wrong lol…

You can add the public int pretty much anywhere, as long as its not in a statement such as a void.
So you can add it at the end of client.java, on top of a void (but not in it!)[/quote]

Ok now you are saying I can throw the int anywhere as long as it isn’t in a void? <_<

Read full topic

item.title: Starter
item.dc:creator: @Rog3r Rog3r
item.description:
@Rog3r wrote:

Wrong lol…

You can add the public int pretty much anywhere, as long as its not in a statement such as a void.
So you can add it at the end of client.java, on top of a void (but not in it!)

item.title: Starter
item.dc:creator: @zero_fly zero fly
item.description:
@zero_fly wrote:

[quote=“Project Evolution, post:20, topic:228875”]Try declaring,

public boolean starter = false;

And then under,

} else if (starter == 1) {

in your command, add this,

starter();

Might not work if you already declared starter. But by the looks of it, you dident.[/quote]
Yah now iget it
U have to add public int starter = 0;
In the public ints lol

Read full topic

item.title: Starter
item.dc:creator: @Rog3r Rog3r
item.description:
@Rog3r wrote:

Wrong lol…

A boolean can only do false and true statements when an int can do numbers.
So don’t add public boolean add this:

public int starter = false;

So its standerd it’ll be false, so if you do the command starter, it will turn it to true, and in the command code it will show if starter = 1, then it’ll send a message and end the code, without adding a item.

Read full topic

item.title: Starter
item.dc:creator: @Project_Evolution Project Evolution
item.description:
@Project_Evolution wrote:

Try declaring,

public boolean starter = false;

And then under,

} else if (starter == 1) {

in your command, add this,

starter();

Might not work if you already declared starter. But by the looks of it, you dident.

Read full topic
